subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage an infant with seborrhoeic dermatitis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Reassure the parent/carer that infantile seborrhoeic dermatitis is not a serious condition — it does not usually trouble the infant and typically resolves spontaneously within a few months.
    • Patient information is available from:
      • The British Association of Dermatologists — Seborrhoeic dermatitis.
      • The National Eczema Association — Infantile seborrhoeic dermatitis.
  • If the scalp is affected (the most common presentation):
    • Advise the parent/carer to massage a topical emollient (such as olive or vegetable oil) onto the scalp to loosen scales, brush gently with a soft brush and wash off with shampoo.
      • Thicker scales can be soaked overnight with white petroleum jelly, vegetable or olive oil, and shampooed in the morning.
    • If this is not effective consider prescribing a topical imidazole cream (clotrimazole 1% or miconazole):
      • Clotrimazole 1% cream: apply 2–3 times daily for up to 4 weeks.
      • Miconazole 2% cream: apply twice daily for up to 4 weeks.
    • If symptoms persist longer than 4 weeks with treatment, seek specialist advice.
  • If areas other than the scalp are affected (including the nappy area):
    • Advise bathing the infant every day using an emollient as a soap substitute; avoid soaps/detergents and vigorous cleansing.
      • Encourage frequent nappy changes and use of barrier emollients such as Zinc and Castor Oil ointment BP or white soft paraffin BP ointment.
    • Consider prescribing a topical imidazole (clotrimazole 1% or miconazole) — treat for up to 4 weeks until symptoms resolve.
      • If symptoms persist longer than 4 weeks with treatment, seek specialist advice.
    • Topical corticosteroids are not usually advised — low potency topical corticosteroids (such as 1% hydrocortisone) may be helpful for some infants with nappy rash.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Nappy rash.
  • Routine follow up is not usually required, however, the parent/carer should be advised to seek review if:
    • Response to treatment is poor.
    • Symptoms worsen despite treatment.
    • Signs of infection (for example crusting, oozing, and bleeding) develop.
  • If symptoms recur:
    • Consider repeating a course of treatment if confident that the diagnosis is correct — seek specialist advice if diagnosis is uncertain.
  • Consider referral to a dermatologist/paediatrician if there is:
    • Severe or widespread seborrhoeic dermatitis — consider possible serious underlying conditions such as immunodeficiency.
    • Diagnostic uncertainty.
    • Failure to respond to routine treatment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on treatment of seborrhoeic dermatitis in infants are based on clinical guidance from the World Health Organisation Evidence and recommendations on seborrhoeic dermatitis [WHO, 2014], Evidence-based Danish guidelines for the treatment of Malassezia-related skin diseases [Hald, 2015] and the Primary Care Dermatological Society Seborrhoeic eczema [PCDS, 2016], and expert opinion from the British Association of Dermatology [BAD, 2018], Rook’s textbook of dermatology [Wakelin, 2016] and review articles [Ooi, 2014; Clark, 2015; BMJ Best Practice, 2018].

Simple advice
  • Recommendations on simple measures are based on expert opinion in clinical guidelines [Hald, 2015], a textbook of dermatology [Wakelin, 2016] and review articles [Ooi, 2014; Clark, 2015; BMJ Best Practice, 2018].
  • Infantile seborrhoeic dermatitis is usually self-limiting and resolves by four months of age. In some babies it may persist for 8–12 months (or longer) [Gary, 2013; Ooi, 2014; Hald, 2015].
Topical preparations
  • CKS has extrapolated recommendations on frequency of application of clotrimazole and miconazole cream from the British National Formulary [BNF 76, 2018] and the manufacturers' Summaries of Product Characteristics [ABPI, 2016a; ABPI, 2016b].
  • Ketoconazole is not licenced for use in infants [BNF 76, 2018].
Recurrence
  • CKS could find no systematic reviews of the treatment of recurrent episodes of seborrhoeic dermatitis in infants.
  • As infantile seborrhoeic dermatitis usually resolves within several weeks to several months, is self-limiting and the course is generally short, CKS does not recommend prophylactic measures, but suggests reviewing the diagnosis if symptoms persist.
Review
  • CKS could find no guidelines or evidence on the follow up of seborrhoeic dermatitis in infants, and therefore recommendations are pragmatic based on clinical good practice. 
Referral
  • The recommendation to refer if there is diagnostic uncertainty or the person is not responding to topical treatment is supported by clinical guidance [PCDS, 2016] and expert opinion in a review article [Ooi, 2014].
  • Generalized seborrhoeic dermatitis is uncommon in otherwise healthy children and usually is associated with immune deficiencies — referral to identify a serious underlying cause is indicated [WHO, 2014; Wakelin, 2016].
